Context:
This diploma program focuses on environmental systems design, operation, and maintenance in heating, ventilation, air conditioning, and refrigeration (HVAC/R) for both residential and commercial sectors. Students will gain practical skills through hands-on experience and competency with industry-standard practices as established by HRAI, ASHRAE, and the Canada Green Building Council. The program requires students to complete semester 2 during the summer after enrolling in January to continue into semester 3 in the fall.

Graduates of this program will be prepared for various careers in the HVAC field including technician roles in installation, maintenance, and repair. Additionally, graduates can challenge the Gas Fitter 2 provincial qualification exam and obtain certification if successful (75 per cent passing grade). For semester 3's Building Code for HVAC course, students are assisted in preparing to challenge the Ontario Ministry of Consumer Affairs and Housing HVAC House exam, which can lead to obtaining a "Building Code Identification Number" (BCIN) upon successful completion.

Note: There is further information regarding BCIN available on the Ontario Building Code website.

Career Options:
- Technicians install, maintain, and repair heating, air conditioning, and refrigeration systems for commercial and residential buildings.
- Sales positions in HVAC industry.
- System balancing roles.
- Cost-estimating for projects.
- Self-employment opportunities in the gas heating industry after obtaining Gas Fitter 2 certification.

Please remember to visit the Ontario Building Code website for more information on BCIN requirements.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Heating, Refrigeration, and Air Conditioning Technician Program T160 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The above text provides information about the required courses for a program at George Brown College focused on Heating, Ventilation, Air Conditioning (HVAC). The courses are offered in four semesters, and some general education electives are also mentioned. Here's a factual summary of the content:

1. Qualification exams for this program are administered by the Province of Ontario, and George Brown College is not responsible for their administration or marking.
2. Semester 1 courses include BLDG 1086 - Building Science and Green Technologies, HVAC related courses (HVAC 1001, HVAC 1006, HVAC 1018), MATH 1145 - Math for HVAC 1, COMM 2000 - Communicating Across Contexts.
3. Semester 2 courses include HVAC 1003, HVAC 1008, HVAC 1016, HVAC 2003, HVAC 2013, MATH 1155, and a general education elective (GNED).
4. Semester 3 courses include HVAC 1017, HVAC 1022, HVAC 2012, HVAC 2014, PORT 1001, and another general education elective.
5. Semester 4 courses include HVAC 1021, HVAC 2001, HVAC 2006, COMM 1113, and a general education elective.
6. Students might be required to take COMM 1000 before progressing to COMM 2000, which doesn't count towards graduation requirements but will incur additional charges.
7. General Education Electives have detailed course outlines and program learning outcomes, which are not provided in the text.

Learning Outcomes (from the text):
1. Relate effectively to heating, refrigeration and air conditioning supervisors, coworkers and customers.
2. Work safely and in accordance with all applicable acts, regulations, legislation and codes to ensure personal and public safety.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Heating, Refrigeration, and Air Conditioning Technician Program T160 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
Program Information:
- The program covers applicable acts, regulations, legislation and codes for personal and public safety.
- Students will use a variety of heating, refrigeration and air conditioning tools and equipment safely and properly.
- Math and applied science problems are required to install and maintain heating, refrigeration and air conditioning systems.
- Preparation and interpretation of electrical, mechanical and piping drawings is part of the program.
- Students will install, service and troubleshoot heating, refrigeration, air conditioning systems and associated components.
- Strategies for ongoing personal and professional development are taught to enhance work performance and career opportunities.

Tuition Fees:
- Domestic Tuition (Fall 2023): $3,964.00
- International Tuition (Fall 2023): $18,001.00
- Disclaimer: fees are subject to change and may not include books.

Admission Requirements:
- Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent
- Grade 12 English (C or U)
- Grade 11 Math (M or U) or grade 12 (C or U)
- Mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English and Math, OR may consider upgrading.

Program Approval:
- OSAP funding is approved for this program if applicant meets eligibility criteria.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Heating, Refrigeration, and Air Conditioning Technician Program T160 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The George Brown College accepts applications for admissions with a focus on English and Math assessments, or the opportunity to upgrade in those subjects. Applicants may need grades above minimum requirements to gain admission to the program. Course exemptions based on college or university credits can be found on the Transfer Guide.

International students should refer to the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements. Domestic students are advised to apply through Ontario Colleges, while international students should use the George Brown College Online Application System.

The School of Apprenticeship and Skilled Trades can be contacted at 416-415-5000 ext. 6711 or via email at skilledtrades@georgebrown.ca, with their office located at Casa Loma Campus, Room E308. For general information about the college, applicants may contact the Contact Centre at 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002.

George Brown offers information sessions on campus and related programs such as Heating, Refrigeration, and Air Conditioning Technology (T162), Electrical Techniques (T167), and Plumbing Techniques (T165). Applicants can book a campus tour or sign up to receive tailored resources for their application process.

Contact information for international recruitment representatives is available on the International Contact Us page, allowing applicants to book virtual meetings or submit inquiries.

Prospective students are encouraged to visit the college's website to explore programs and gather more information.
